preface.title: Preface
preface.para: If you're reading this then you are now an officer (or should be) in the WVU ACM or FSG.

You're not only a part of one of the most active and successful clubs on campus, you're taking a role in leading it. In just two years we were able to take a club of humble origins and turn it in the club to be watched on the Engineering campus. We're in the business of making things happen and you will be too.

In just the past several years, we've hosted events such as Richard Stallman's talk on Copyright, John Perry Barlow's discussion on political unrest in the Middle East, and Corey Haines Test-Driven Development code retreat. Through FSG, we were able to get free alternatives installed in campus computer labs.

As an officer of ACM & FSG, you have a responsibility to keep the fire burning; to keep organizing awesome events that engage students and get them asking questions. Perhaps you'll change their point of view or introduce them to ideas that change their lives.

section.title: The Free Software Group
section.para:
The Free Software Group (FSG) was founded in 2008 as an organization separate to the ACM. That year we realized that we could accomplish so much more if we worked together as sister organizations. An article was featured in the Daily Athenaeum to cover FSG's founding.
http://www.thedaonline.com/newest-student-org-connects-to-campus-1.700949

Seeing as the ACM is a national organization based mainly on research in the field of Computer Science and Engineering, a club needed to exist to promote Free Software on campus and host events centered on Free Software.

example.title: The WVU Free Software Group Manifesto
example.para: Raise Awareness, distribute, and encourage the adoption and installation of free software to the Student Body, Morgantown Community, and in Campus Computing Facilities.

section.para: ACM & FSG have different goals as organizations. While ACM & FSG work very closely to plan events, it is important that the two clubs remain separate entities. Free Software doesn't appeal to every Computer Science student on campus which is why the ACM pushes forward events that will appeal to the majority of LCSEE.
